instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.19v
threads.message:
Hello
any help will be much appreciated. <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> logic board not powering up. 
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> measures 5.19V
Found corrosion on CC773,CB211,CC772. Replaced all with the same result. Also replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL>: 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL>: 5.19V

No other corrosion seen anywhere else.

Any suggestion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.19v
threads.message: These typically aren’t the most fun. Corrosion near or under any of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips? Corrosion near <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.19v
threads.message:
The board has 4 USB-C controllers (CD3215A).
SMC needs to talk with all 4 before activate the full charger voltage.
<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and UB000 also should work.
If SPI chip <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> cannot be accessed, you can't get more than 5.2V.
Bad thing is that SMC will not allow <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to generate <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, even it can work with only 5V.

Compare resistance to ground on similar lines around the 4 CD3215A.
Not only power rails, compare data lines too.
Probably only one port is damaged...
Try first to reflow affected areas, using quality flux, to burn crap.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.19v
threads.message:
There was corrosion near <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>. When i plug the charge to that port, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> starts to cycle between 3.4v and 0.9v. When i plug to the second usb-c port on the same side, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>
 holds at 3.39v. 

And resistance reading not finding any shorts. But going to keep checking the lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.19v
threads.message: Start with flux and heat under <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>. See if you get any change

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.19v
threads.message: No change with flux and heating the chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.19v
threads.message: "Compare resistance to ground on similar lines around the 4 CD3215A."

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.19v
threads.message: Yeah best to check now for signals near <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>. Compare <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> and all of the LDO signals 3v3 1v8 etc around <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> to the other 3 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips. My guess is one of your lines will be being pulled low near one of the chips by either a cap or a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.19v
threads.message: In resistance mode as 2informaticos suggested or in diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.19v
threads.message:
Always start in diode mode.
If no reading, then switch to ohm mode...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.19v
threads.message:
Sorry took so long to respond. Was out of town. 

In diode mode:
<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and UB400
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> has a zero reading. Resistance mode measures about the same with the other 2 chips, high resistance in the 1M range.

Wondering if i should replace <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> which is close to the capacitors i found corrosion on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.19v
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> has a zero reading."
Do you mean 000, or OL?
You cannot read high resistance in a zero reading line...

Crap under <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> can block the controller.
But you must compare readings for all controllers in more points, not only two.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.19v
threads.message: Correction it was OL. And i did check other lines and compared them between all 4 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, and they were all comparable except the two mentioned.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5.19v
threads.message:
OL doesn't mean zero at all...

You get differences at <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> for that two lines comparing with the other 3 chips?
In such case change <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.
You can try a reflow with quality flux first.; in case there is crap underneath.
